          Kenneth Arrow Won Nobel in Economics and Dazzled Colleagues

          Kenneth Arrow, considered one of the greatest economists of the post-World War II era, was virtually unknown to the general public but revered by colleagues. In 1972, at age 51, he became the youngest winner of the Nobel Prize for economics. Dr. Arrow died Feb. 21 at 95.

          Michael Novak Crafted a Moral Defense of Democratic Capitalism

          Michael Novak wrote more than 50 books, including the acclaimed “Spirit of Democratic Capitalism,” a 1982 work that made a moral case for capitalism. Mr. Novak died Feb. 17 at 83.
